article.description: Chris Webber is back. It just took him a while to get going.

related.description:
Chris Webber is back, even
though the Sacramento Kings hardly missed him.
related.linkText: Webber activated, playing for Kings tonight
related.title: Kings have been 15-5 without star player
related.headline: Kings have been 15-5 without star player

article.headline: Webber finds his groove in second half for 18 points

images.name: Stojankovic_Peja 120901 inline
images.caption: Peja Stojakovic got loose for a team-high 23 points for Sacramento.

article.linkText: Webber, nervous at first, makes his return to Kings
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- Chris Webber is back. It just took him a while to get going. "Just walking on the court was the best feeling tonight," said Webber, who scored 14 of his 18 points in the second half Sunday night in his first game for Sacramento this season as the Kings beat Miami 95-88. "It feels like I'm on training wheels again," Webber said. "All I wanted to do was get back. I asked the coach if he had any advice for a nervous, energetic guy and he just said, `Be yourself."' Webber, who missed the first 20 games of the season with a sprained right ankle, was activated from the injured list and played 28 minutes to help lead the Kings to their third consecutive victory and sixth in seven games. "He came out and played extremely well," teammate Bobby Jackson said. "He is going to do a lot of things for us. He brings a lot to the team." Peja Stojakovic scored 23 points, Doug Christie barely missed his first double-double of the season with 18 points and nine rebounds, and Hedo Turkoglu added 15 points for the Kings, who made a season-high 30 free throws. Jim Jackson, in his third game with the Heat after signing as a free agent on Dec. 2, had a double-double with 17 points and 11 rebounds in Miami's 13th defeat in 14 games. LaPhonso Ellis and Jimmy Jones each had 14 points and Alonzo Mourning added 13. Webber, who received a standing ovation from the crowd at Arco Arena when his name was announced with Sacramento's starters, played nearly eight minutes in his first stint on the court, going 2-for-4 from the floor with three rebounds and an assist. He was limited to nine minutes in the first half due to foul trouble. "He was so excited to play he got out of sync there in the first half," Kings coach Rick Adelman said. "It was nice to have him back, and he's just going to get better the more he plays." Adelman said he had no thoughts of easing Webber into the lineup, that as long as he's healthy he'll start. "He needs to get in the game early," he said. "He's our best player and we need to get him playing. He made some big shots in the fourth quarter." With 8:47 remaining in the third quarter, Webber was fouled hard by Heat forward Brian Grant, and was shoved in the back by Ellis, who was hit with a technical foul. While Christie was shooting the first two foul shots, Grant was nailed with a technical foul for excessive arguing. Webber then made his free throws to put the Kings up 67-57, their biggest lead of the night. "He's a big-time player and he did what he was supposed to do," Jackson said. "He made some big shots at the end of the game and they kept him fresh for the fourth quarter. He's an All-Star, he makes plays like that. I wish he wouldn't, but he does." Sacramento took a 76-70 lead into the fourth quarter, and maintained the lead the rest of the way. Miami closed to four points several times in the final period, but could get no closer. "We were fighting uphill all game long," Miami coach Pat Riley said. "We didn't make the plays we had to make in the fourth quarter." Christie scored nine points in the first quarter, including a reverse layup in the final two seconds that put the Kings up 26-24. Stojakovic was 10-for-12 from the foul line, and scored 13 points, as Sacramento took a 54-47 lead into halftime. Game notes
Sacramento forward Lawrence Funderburke went on the injured list with right Achilles' tendinitis, making room for Webber. ... Kings guard Brent Price celebrated his 33rd birthday Sunday. ... The Kings matched their best start since the franchise's first season in Rochester, when the 1948-49 team also went 16-5. ... Miami is off to its worst start since the first year of the franchise, 1988-89, when they began 1-17, with the victory coming in game No. 18. ... Sacramento forward Gerald Wallace had his high school jersey (No. 45) retired Saturday in Childersburg, Ala. ... Adelman is one victory away from 500 in his career. ... Miami has yet to shoot 50 percent or better this season.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
